Situation1: A minor misunderstanding about weekend plans just arose.
Expectation2: Arrive at the polling station during designated voting hours
Situation2: Late-afternoon errands leave just a couple of hours before the polls close.
Story: I glance at my phone and see a text from Mia: “I thought we were spending Saturday together. Why didn’t you tell me about your plans?” My heart sinks. I’d promised her we’d talk through things better, especially after last month’s argument. I want to call her right away, to clear up the misunderstanding before it grows into something bigger. But as I check the time, I realize the polling station closes in less than two hours. I’d meant to vote earlier, but errands ran late, and now I’m cutting it close. I know how much voting matters to me—my voice, my responsibility. But Mia’s voice is trembling in my head, her expectation that I’ll be there for her, that I’ll put us first. I feel torn, my chest tight with the pressure of choosing. If I rush to vote, I risk letting her down again. If I call her now, I might miss my chance to vote. Both roles demand something of me, and I can’t see a way to meet them both. I stand frozen, phone in hand, keys in the other, caught between the two worlds I’m supposed to belong to.
